text: I feel fortunate to witness the global higher education landscape from both a macro and micro lens. Across boardrooms, campuses, and policy halls, change is afoot - not always loud, but absolutely real!At Acumen, Part of Sannam S4 Group, we are seeing these shifts through student choices, partner priorities, and on-the-ground actions across geographies. author: Mark-Anthony Johnson
text: China, Kenya upgrade ties amid 'turbulent international situation' China and Kenya announced they had upgraded ties to a "new level" on Thursday during a meeting between President Xi Jinping and Kenyan President William Ruto in hashtag#Beijing, as they both pledged to create an "all-weather" China Africa community.In a joint China-Kenya statement, both leaders said they were "committed to injecting more stability into the world with the certainty of China-Africa solidarity and cooperation".This would provide a backbone to safeguard the "common interests of developing countries", it said, and defend the multilateral system, via "inclusive economic globalisation".The decision to upgrade China-Kenya relations was made "in the face of a turbulent international situation", the Chinese president was quoted as saying in a separate media pool report.Africa is a key focus of Xi's ambitious hashtag#BeltandRoadInitiative, launched in 2013 to extend China's geopolitical and economic influence through global hashtag#infrastructure development.Kenya has been a key hashtag#BRI recipient, and Nairobi has taken a raft of loans from hashtag#China to finance infrastructure hashtag#construction projects that have made China the East African nation's biggest bilateral lender.Among new projects announced by the Kenyan presidency on Thursday, China will invest in the extension of a standard gauge railway to the border with hashtag#Uganda. Completion of the line has stalled since 2019 due to lack of funds.China will also invest in the expansion of a major highway linking the capital hashtag#Nairobi with the Rift Valley city of Nakuru, through a public-private partnership model, it said. Ruto's office did not provide details on the deals, but previous Kenyan government estimates have put their value in the billions of dollars each.Xi and Ruto signed 20 documents together on Thursday, according to a media pool report. These included agreements on science and technology cooperation, vocational education, water resources, ecommerce, intelligent transport systems and the railway sector.Kenya has been struggling with a heavy hashtag#debt load and the accompanying cost of servicing it.Ruto, who took office in September 2022, has promised that his government will not default on its external debt, pledging to cut waste and boost revenue to tackle the challenge.It is Ruto's first state visit to China as president of hashtag#Kenya. author: Sivakumar Babuji
text: The dedication and hard work of Maths teacher Abdul Malik, who lives in a small village in the southern state of Kerala, India, has become an example. In the last 20 years, he has never been late to reach school, nor has he taken a single day off. Even today, he goes to school by swimming across the river with the help of a rubber tyre, carrying a bag on his head, so that no child's studies are interrupted. Abdul Malik shared this unique life journey of his in the BBC program Outlook.About his village, he tells that it may be a small and ordinary village, but its biggest feature is the tradition of education here. Education has been given importance here for generations and this is the reason why many teachers reside in this small village.When Abdul Malik was asked why he chose the path of becoming a teacher, his answer was, "Becoming a teacher not only makes us better citizens ourselves, but also gives an opportunity to show the right direction to others. Education is the medium that makes us an ideal for children."The school Malik goes to teach is in a village across the Kadalundi river. If he goes by road, the distance to the school is about seven kilometers, while by river the distance is just one kilometer. This village is surrounded by the river on three sides and there is neither a doctor nor any other teacher here. In such a situation, dedicated teachers like Malik are the light of the future of the children of this village.hashtag#Inspiration hashtag#Motivation hashtag#Leadership hashtag#LinkedIn hashtag#India

text: When I was 17, I secured a full scholarship that promised to change my life. To the funders, it was an easy sell: â€œInvest in this child, sheâ€™ll be the first in her family to graduate.â€ The theory behind this pitch seemed sound. In practice, the reality was more complex.Three years later, only 30% of my cohort earned their qualification. A significant portion didnâ€™t even make it past the first year. So, what happened? Were these students ungrateful? Were they not taking advantage of the opportunities given to them? And what didnâ€™t we get right?The truth is, there were many layers to this situation. Yes, the students needed the scholarship, but they also needed far more than just academic support. They needed psychosocial support.Many of us were uprooted from our homes, some from child-headed households, leaving behind siblings who depended on us. Part of the allowance we received was sent back home to help our families. I distinctly remember one of my peers, who was constantly distracted by thoughts of a sick sibling back home, despite being in class.These were the realities of where we came from.Years later, Iâ€™m heartened to see that the conversation around education has evolved. What started as a question of â€œHow many students can we fund with X amount of money?â€ has shifted to â€œWhat would be the real impact of investing in this program?â€ or "How best can we support these students?"Itâ€™s a welcomed mindset shift that recognizes the deeper, multifaceted support children need to truly succeed.Investing in education is no longer just about funding a seat in a classroom. Itâ€™s about nurturing the whole person, emotionally, mentally, and socially, to help them thrive, both in their studies and in life.

text: Prof. Krishnaswamy Kasturirangan (1940â€“2025)India mourns the passing of Prof. Krishnaswamy Kasturirangan, a towering figure in science and education, who breathed his last at the age of 85.
